title: Viacom, Inc. (VIAB) CEO Philippe Dauman on Q2 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript
body: Viacom, Inc. (NASDAQ:VIAB) Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call April 28, 2016  8:30 AM ET
Executives
James Bombassei – Senior Vice President-Investor Relations
Philippe Dauman – Executive Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
Wade Davis – Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President Viacom, Inc.
Thomas Dooley – Chief Operating Officer & Director
Analysts
Alexia Quadrani – JPMorgan Securities
John Janedis – Jefferies
Doug Mitchelson – UBS Securities
Brian Wieser – Pivotal Research Group
Vasily Karasyov – CLSA Americas
Benjamin Mogil – Stifel, Nicolaus & Co., Inc.
Omar Sheikh – Credit Suisse Securities
Daniel Salmon – BMO Capital Markets
Operator

Good day everyone, and welcome to Viacom's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Teleconference. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Jim Bombassei. Please go ahead.
James Bombassei

Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our March quarter earnings call. Joining me for today's discussion are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President, and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer.

Please note that in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. I want to refer you to page number two in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements, and involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website.
And now I'll turn the call over to Philippe.
Philippe Dauman

Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-term affiliate revenue growth, increasing value generated from the growing use of technology and data, and continued growth in our international business. We made solid progress in the quarter, driving significant change across our brands to increase the value of our content and better position us for the future.

There are four major strategic objectives driving change and future growth at Viacom. First and foremost, we continue to make substantial investments in content, specifically original content, long-term imperative that is generating clear results and building long-term value. This includes steadily escalating content investments in television and film, as well as short-form mobile content.

Second, we are upgrading and expanding our already substantial data capabilities to deliver more accurate metrics for advertisers and greater monetization potential. We are out in the lead in this area and are beginning to reap the benefit which will accelerate as we go forward.

Third, we are maximizing our opportunities for revenue growth with traditional distributors while moving forward with new forms of distribution. Our content ownership and the popularity of our content on new platforms and social media are providing new options as the ecosystem evolves.

And fourth, we continue to look at strategic options to enhance our competitive position and unlock the value of our businesses. Our exploration of a strategic minority investor in Paramount is an excellent example, as is our continued international expansion.

Looking at the numbers, in the second quarter, revenues declined 3% to $3 billion. Adjusted operating income was $586 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $303 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined to $0.76 per diluted share.

Turning to Media Networks, revenues declined 3% to $2.38 billion in the quarter. Ad sales revenues were down 5% in the U.S. While it is early in the quarter, we hope to improve the rate of change in ad sales revenue, even as we reduce unit load at several of our networks, which bodes well for brand health and future financial performance. This year, we expect a strong upfront, a tripling of Viacom Vantage client, and additional interest in kids, where Viacom has some of its greatest strength. The movie studios are coming to this upfront with an increased number of kids and family oriented theatrical releases, and as a dominant kids' network, this is very positive for Nickelodeon. In addition, we have recently launched Viacom Vantage Studio Edition, the first data driven ad product specifically for the studio category, where we see significant opportunities for overall growth.

Domestic affiliate revenues in the current quarter decreased 2%, impacted as we had previously discussed by the rate realignment with a major distributor and slight declines in distribution in line with industry trend. SVOD revenues are expected to be more significant in the second half of our fiscal year. Based on the long-term deals we've recently closed, we expect to grow affiliate revenues with traditional distributors and overall, at mid-single-digit rates in 2017 – when the rate realignment will be behind us – and beyond.

Our recent renewal with DISH on favorable terms was an important moment for Viacom. In the past year, we have successfully renewed distribution deals with several major distributors representing over 44 million subscribers. We now have long term deals in place with all of the major distributors and an extended runway for steady affiliate revenue growth.

We have a real opportunity to build on that momentum. Our networks are highly valued by our cable, satellite and Telco partners because they drive substantial live and video-on-demand viewership. In fact, the reach of our networks is vastly underappreciated. We continue to own the largest share of viewership in multiple key demographics on a highly monetizable cable television platform. Viacom networks combined represents the largest share of cable viewing of any cable family for all viewers 2+ according to Nielsen. And we gained more share compared to a year ago than any other family of cable networks among viewers 2 to 49, where we have 21% of viewership. We also have the largest share of viewers 18 to 34, also 21%, and 18 to 49 at over 17%. The significance of this share shift will become even more evident as new more robust measurement tools take hold in the market.

In addition, our networks and the demos they attract are much desired for OTT streaming services from new entrants in the industry, as well as those developed by the traditional distributors such as Sling. While cable penetration continues to decline across the industry, the penetration of connected devices is growing at a double-digit clip. In fact, 34% of broadband households subscribe to two or more paid Internet video services. The Viacom network portfolio is a leader in the U.S. among broadband-only homes, and drives significant viewership on long-form platforms like Amazon, Hulu, and Roku, as well as on short-form platforms like YouTube and Snapchat.

Viacom's strong position as a valued content provider in both traditional cable and the fast-growing broadband and mobile universe will continue to work in our favor as we lead the content providers into this new world. It gives us great confidence that our brand's connections with valuable audiences are as strong as ever. We will maintain our focus on improving traditional ratings, and also work to increase monetization in broadband-powered distribution by collaborating with our partners on subscription models and advertising features that will make these platforms more economically attractive.

One of the ways we're meeting these challenges is by continuing to expand our data and ad technology capabilities, exemplified by today's announcement with Roku. Among connected device owners, Roku homes have the highest reach, average days used and hours used per day. In fact, Roku usage is greater than Xbox, Chromecast, and Apple TV combined, and that lead is accelerating. This first of its kind partnership will allow us to leverage aggregate data from Roku, enabling sophisticated ad targeting at an unprecedented scale in the TV environment. Through this partnership, we can offer better, more targeted ad product. We also have a financial investment in Roku.

Combined with partnerships with comScore, TiVo, Symphony, Snapchat, and several others, a continuing relationship with Nielsen and our expanding internal expertise, we're building a platform that's second to none. There is no question that Internet delivery is here to stay, and we continue to grow quickly through new and bigger OTT and SVOD services, as well as an improving TV Everywhere experience.

Now turning to a brief update on our media networks. We are rejuvenating and repositioning several of our networks and seeing positive results. Viacom had eight of the top 30 ad-supported cable networks in the 2-plus demo and nine of the top 30 in the 18 to 49 demo, one more than last year in each. We also had the highest number of top 20 cable series among core demos.

Nickelodeon continues its leading performance, taking the number one spot in 2 to 11 for 37 consecutive weeks, and pulling away from its competitors on a total day and head-to-head basis. Blaze and The Monster Machines was the number one program across all television with young kids for the second consecutive quarter. Among kids 2 to 11, Nickelodeon owned the top two animated shows, SpongeBob SquarePants and Alvin, and four of the top five programs throughout the quarter.

On the consumer products side, Paw Patrol is the number one preschool property with every mass retailer. The property is a success in nearly every licensed product category, including preschool toys where it is number one, apparel, home goods, and accessory.

VH1's ratings were the best in six years, with strong double-digit gains across the board. At Spike, Lip Sync Battle remains the most watched original series in the channel's history and in season two continues to deliver a big and a broad audience. It's also a global hit, now in more than 120 countries.

Bellator, which Spike acquired in 2011, is another global success story. Currently the fastest growing combat sports franchise worldwide, Bellator is averaging 1.2 million viewers this year, a 45% increase over 2015. Bellator held its first European event in Torino, Italy this month, with two additional international events planned this year, the first in London and airing on Viacom's channel 5, and the second in Israel. We expect Bellator to grow into a significant Viacom asset in its own right.

At MTV, overall ratings remain soft, but MTV's programming continues to capture substantial audience share with five of the top 25 programs on cable among viewers 12 to 34. Under new overall and programming leadership, MTV is committed to bringing more live music and music inspired programming to the network. Last week, MTV put on a reimagined upfront event that was very warmly received by the ad community. The upcoming slate features 14 new series and specials fueled by top tier producing talent like Mark Burnett and, including Wonderland, the network's first weekly live music performance series in nearly 20 years, that debuts this fall.

At Comedy Central, changing viewing patterns continue to impact ratings, but declines narrowed significantly versus the prior quarter. Comedy Central continues to develop hit new programming, including this quarter's Not Safe with Nikki Glaser, and is returning popular multi-platform shows such as Inside Amy Schumer, Broad City, Tosh.0 and Another Period. The turnaround of MTV and Comedy Central will be a driver of our advertising revenue recovery as we head into our next fiscal year.

Viacom's International Media Networks performance continues to be strong, with even more growth on horizon. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, advertising revenues increased 6% in the quarter and affiliate revenues rose 11% in the quarter. This is an important and underappreciated part of our portfolio that has grown significantly and now includes the Paramount Channel, Channel 5, Viacom18, Spike, Comedy, as well as even better, more localized MTV and Nickelodeon networks. Ratings are strong in our international brands, particularly MTV.

In India, Viacom and our JV partner have 16 networks and a country-leading position. We are showing strong growth in regional markets and have recently launched Voot, an advertising-supported VOD platform that will house COLORS, MTV and Nick content, as well as original long and short-form content.

In the UK, our brands continue to show solid growth. Channel 5 reached its highest share ever in the 16 to 34 demo in the quarter, and MTV, Nick, and Comedy all posted double-digit share increases. Nickelodeon remains the number one kids' channel group in paid television.

International markets also give us a valuable opportunity to experiment with new digital platforms and monetization strategies. For example, Play Plex, a flexible app-based distribution platform for all of Viacom's global brands, can help our paid TV operator partners create a great TV Everywhere experience for consumers, or be distributed as an over-the-top service. We are particularly excited about Play Plex as an authenticated or direct-to-consumer mobile product in markets without cable and pay TV infrastructure.

Paramount results were disappointing this quarter, largely due to two titles that performed below expectations. We look forward to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the current quarter and Star Trek Beyond, Ben-Hur, Jack Reacher 2, Rings, and several other promising titles later in the year. Paramount Television continues to make rapid progress, with 15 shows ordered to production and an additional 10 set up at networks, including Maniac, a comedy starring Emma Stone and Jonah Hill for Netflix.

Turning to EPIX, we are looking forward to the introduction of its first two original scripted series in the fall, including Paramount's Berlin Station. EPIX has the youngest audience of all of the major premium services, and was the fastest growing premium network in the U.S., growing more than 35% year-over-year in 2015. The process of identifying a strategic minority investor in Paramount is continuing and on track to securing an agreement by the end of June. The strategic and valuation possibilities are compelling. Like the entire media industry, the motion picture business is evolving. A strong strategic partner for Paramount, particularly one that provides international and/or technological clout and expertise will provide important benefits to both Paramount and Viacom.

In summary, we are creating more and more original programming under revitalized network leadership, and that is bearing fruit both in the U.S. and abroad. We have secured renewals with all of our major U.S. distribution affiliates. We are entering into partnerships with a number of new market entrants, including Snapchat, Roku, comScore, and more. Our international expansion will provide opportunities to drive significant value and growth for Viacom for the foreseeable future, and Paramount is poised for renewed success, driven by a full slate and a vibrant television business.

Our entire management team is completely focused on putting the building blocks for growth in place this year. We have a smart strategy and are investing in our properties in the U.S. and around the world, setting us up to become a growth story in fiscal 2017 and beyond.
Thank you. And now I'll turn it over to Wade.
Wade Davis

Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you to our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our March quarter are available on our website. Now, let's take a look at our segment results.

At our Media Networks segment revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 4% and international revenues were substantially flat. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 7%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. Page nine of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance.

In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 4% in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 5% and international revenues were down 1%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe.

In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%, domestic revenues declined 2% in the quarter, reflecting a modest decline in subscribers and a previously disclosed rate adjustment with a major distributor, partially offset by rate increases across the remaining subscriber base. Excluding a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues increased 11%, driven by new channel launches, increased subscribers, and rate increases.

Expenses increased 2% in the quarter. In operating expenses, programming expenses were up 6%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 10%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The increase in programming costs was due to our ongoing investment in original content. The decrease in SG&A cost was principally due to lower advertising and promotional expenses.

Within Media Networks, adjusted operating income was down 11% for the quarter and the adjusted operating income margin was 33.8%. Decline in operating income was driven by the 3 percentage point decrease in revenue and the 2% increase in expense.

Moving to Filmed Entertainment, revenues were down 1% in the quarter principally due to a decrease in home entertainment revenue, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 2 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides a breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues.

Theatrical revenues increased 6% due to higher carryover revenues from Daddy's Home and The Big Short, which were both released late in the December quarter, partially offset by lower revenues from the current quarter releases. Home entertainment revenues decline 21%, reflecting lower revenue from catalog and third-party distribution titles. Revenue from license fees increased 17%, primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand.

Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $136 million in the quarter, as compared to income of $1 million last year. The loss in the quarter primarily reflects the performance of Zoolander 2 and Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.
In terms of taxes, the year to date adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 100 basis point increase as compared to the prior year.
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.
Thomas Dooley

Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt, as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million of free cash flow in the March quarter of last year. Page five of the web deck presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year, principally due to lower adjusted operating income.

Moving on to our debt. It remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at quarter end of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.5 billion total debt and $480 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.3 times. We have $368 million remaining of our outstanding 6.25% senior notes which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off.

Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting the remainder of fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transaction and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability. For the fiscal 2016 year, we continue to expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low/mid-single-digit range.

For the full year, we continue to expect that Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single-digits. Given the timing of shows coming on air in the back half of the year, we expect programming expense growth to be weighted to the June quarter. Additionally, we expect marketing expense to be higher in the June quarter related to the launch of these shows. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.8%.

At Paramount, while it has been a difficult first half of the year, we are looking forward to our summer releases, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. Given the first half performance, we expect the studio to generate a loss in fiscal 2016.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions.
Question-and-Answer Session
Operator
[Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.
Alexia Quadrani

Thank you. Could you provide a bit more color on the domestic ad revenue in the quarter? There seems to be a lot of moving pieces here. On the one hand, you've got improving ratings from your key networks, a healthy scatter market. On the flip side, you've got to make good for previous shortfalls, reduction in ad loads, and still some softness in some of your networks like Comedy Central, MTV. I guess to the extent you can help us maybe piece together some of these different factors, how much they influence the numbers, and really, what is the delta that we should look for ahead to see improvement?
Philippe Dauman

Thank you, Alexia. Well, as we mentioned, we are reducing ad load on several of our networks, and we believe that will improve our brand health overall and help us as we go into the upfront where we'd like to be very strong. There is a strong demand in the scatter market, and pricing is very strong in the scatter market. But as you point out, we have limited inventory available to take advantage of that right now. And what will drive improvement, in addition to several of the networks that I mentioned improving, will be the continuing improvement at Comedy Central and MTV, which are obviously big networks for us, and where we have both have stepped up our level of programming. We have revitalized the leadership at MTV, and a new direction that advertisers welcome, and we will be able to benefit from as we head into the upfront.

Additionally, again relating to the upfront, we now have much enhanced capabilities, driven by our Viacom Vantage and other products, which will help us drive pricing as we go into the upfront and beyond. So we think this is a period where we can, as I mentioned in my remarks, we hope to see -it is very early in the quarter, but we hope to see some improvement this quarter. And we are very focused on improving the overall brand health and going advertisers who really view us as the leading way to reach the key demos they want to reach. So we certainly feel very optimistic about not just the upfront but what that bodes for the broadcast year ahead as we continue to seek improvement as the rest of this year unfolds.
Thomas Dooley
And Alexia, I mean, the unit load reduction is an important step, as Philippe mentioned. If we didn't adjust for the unit loads, we would have been down around 3%.
Alexia Quadrani

Okay. That's helpful. And just a clarification, if I can, on one of the comments in the opening remarks. I think you said on the domestic affiliate side that you hope to get sort of a mid-single-digit range from both traditional and sort of overall. I guess is that correct? Can you get to the single just traditional load, and overall also for maybe at the high end of mid-singles? And can you still see incremental growth – I guess it's implied you can – from over-the-top or SVOD, given you've already benefited so much from those revenue streams?
Philippe Dauman

Yeah, so, I talked about the mid-single-digit for 2017 and beyond. Having now reached agreements with all the major distributors, we have a lot of visibility on rate increases on these long-term agreements, which give us strong visibility. There is, by the way, and you've seen some of the earnings reports by major distributors in the last few days, there does appear to be some stabilization in subscriber count on the part of the distribution community, which is encouraging. And by the way, I think that's a byproduct of more work being done in areas like TV Everywhere, customer service, and the like.

So we certainly now have, especially with the last big major behind us, in DISH, good visibility on traditional, which is why I singled that out. And then overall, we have many opportunities to grow other forms of affiliate revenue, whether it's SVOD platforms, whether it's other over-the-top products, or even Sling, as part of our recent DISH agreement. So, we have some visibility that allows us to project the mid-single-digit. Of course, where we land on that depends a lot on what in fact happens when we go forward on subscriber counts and the like, but I'm encouraged by the stabilization that appears to be taking hold in the marketplace.
Alexia Quadrani
Thank you.
Philippe Dauman
You're welcome, Alexia.
Operator
We'll take our next question from John Janedis with Jeffries.
John Janedis

Hi. Thanks. Good morning. Two quick questions. First, just back to Paramount. Assuming the transaction gets done, can you talk about the use of proceeds and how that may affect the potential to restart the buyback?

And separately, maybe as a back up to Alexia's question, there's been nervousness in the market around the kids' advertising and money shifting to digital platforms. Philippe, you highlighted movies, but what are you seeing from the kids' vertical more broadly, and to what extent are you recapturing the revenue with some of your partnerships?
Philippe Dauman

So, as far as the Paramount transaction, where it's boring, obviously the use of proceeds for that and cash in general for Viacom will be used to obviously bring our leverage ratio back to where we have talked we want to be in for investment-grade purposes. We use our cash as we always have to take advantage of any opportunities that present themselves, either grow our business or strategic acquisitions, like Channel 5, which of course I mentioned in our prior earnings call, turned out to be a home run. And then excess capital will be available to return to shareholders in the form of dividends and buybacks, as we find availability in our buyback program. But we're getting a little ahead of ourselves. Right now, we're working to get a deal done and get those proceeds and deploy them as we do all cash that we've generated [indiscernible].
Thomas Dooley
This advertising market is very, very strong right now. We see no weakness. No shift, actually. Dollars are shifting back from digital into the linear format both in kids and adult.
John Janedis
Thank you very much.
Operator
We'll take our next question from Doug Mitchelson from UBS.
Doug Mitchelson

Oh, thanks so much. Good morning. Philippe, can you talk about how your channels are positioned in Sling TV and if we should think of that as a template for any future virtual MVPD deals the company might do? And any sort of updated thoughts or comments on Comcast re-tiering Sling and CMT, if there's any sort of negotiations taking place or what your thoughts are about that would be helpful. Thank you.
Philippe Dauman

As far as Sling, I'm going to let DISH make its consumer announcement. But I will say that we have a broad array of networks. We did choose to withhold the Nickelodeon network for now from the Sling platform, and we will evaluate that as it goes forward.

And as far as other virtual MVPDs, what we have learned from discussions with various players is that there are different points of view on what the consumer offerings ought to be. So, we're still in an experimental stage in that domain, so I don't expect that you will see commonalty in offerings in the marketplace. It's still early stage and we'll see how it unfolds. And in many cases, particularly for the MVPDs, to the extent they're exploring these, they're looking at it as a gateway to the broader offering of networks that you might view as more traditional, even though the delivery is getting less traditional in that they're using digital delivery and TV Everywhere kind of offerings to consumers.
As far as the Comcast issue relating to re-tiering, we continue to deal with that privately with Comcast at this point rather than make any further comment on that, which we continue to contest.
Doug Mitchelson

Thanks, Philippe, but if I could maybe – maybe I should ask a little more directly on Sling. I think there's some concern because there was a belief in the marketplace that DISH had a lot of leverage in these negotiations that you might have had given up economics at Sling to get a traditional deal done. Any clarification around that would be helpful.
Philippe Dauman

Nothing could be further from the truth. We are very pleased with the terms as I've mentioned in the past. And I've – I know people have been talking about this – had been talking about it for a year and a half, I said all along we have had a long and strong relationship with DISH. I had indicated that we were going to – we were confident that the deal was going to be renewed. And I'm proud to say that we were able to renew it on good terms without our networks being taken away from consumers, unlike about 20 situations involving other programmers at that distributor over the last few years. And we are set up with DISH in a very constructive relationship, with growth in rates over term on both the traditional platform and Sling.

And we have also provided in our DISH deal a lot of new functionality that relates to TV Everywhere and video-on-demand as we, of course, brought the agreement up to date. And I think that will benefit DISH's consumers and again reinforce the ecosystem with this important distributor. And we will continue to look for new ways to work together as we go forward, as we do with all of our affiliates. And we deliver particularly valuable audiences, given our strength in the demos that I talked about in the earnings remarks. You cannot reach millennials in the way that we do. We have the leading family, so if one wants to drive services that appeal to millennials, and some of these new over-the-top products are entry points into media for millennials, we provide core services as demonstrated by the deal that we did.
Doug Mitchelson
Right. Thank you very much.
Philippe Dauman
Welcome, Doug.
Operator
We'll take our next question from Brian Wieser with Pivotal Research.
Brian Wieser

Thanks for taking my question. First, I was curious if you could give some context to the TV studio details you provided with 10 shows and 15 respectively, if you could provide year-ago equivalents or just some context in terms of the traction there.
And separately, any updates in terms of contribution revenue that Vantage might have had in the quarter, or further expectations into the year?
Philippe Dauman

Well, as far as the television operation, it's a start-up. We started Paramount Television less than two years ago from scratch. So the vast majority of the shows were basically picked up over the last – certainly over the last year with a lot of them over the last several months. And as shows have been green lit, they've been making a number of announcements.

Some of them are for our own networks, like School of Rock, which has been ordered for a second season on Nickelodeon, as it's off to a great start. We're looking at an original series for TV Land coming from Paramount Television. We have an original series slated for Spike from Paramount. And this fall, we have Berlin Station on EPIX. That's just our own network. I mentioned Maniac on Netflix. We have other series for SVOD services. We have series on HBO. We have series on Fox. We had Grease: Live out very successful on Fox. We have series on Turner Networks.

We really have series across the board. Some of it original concepts and some of them based on titles in the Paramount library. So there are many, many opportunities to create new series just starting with our own library of great film titles that can be turned into a television series. It, of course, allows us also to sell in the global marketplace. So we're very happy with the rapid lift off. And we think as series get on air, get into multiple seasons, it will be a great leg for Paramount and an important driver of long-term performance for Paramount. And it's certainly an interesting aspect of this as we explore a strategic transaction.

Vantage – I'll let Tom supplement what I have to say on Vantage – but it's been certainly a key part of the conversation with our major branded advertisers. And remember that as I have said previously, over three-quarters of our advertising comes from our top 100 advertisers, and we are in this upfront, expecting to triple the number of Vantage participants to approximately 33 players; take the 33 against the top 100 and think of the 33 as being concentrated in the top 50, so, it's a substantial part of our upfront discussions. And we talk about Vantage and we have all sorts of other services that come with it under the Velocity and Echo capabilities – integrated marketing, social media connectivity, et cetera – and that will grow from there next year. We built up the capability to be able to ramp up to this level and we'll continue to ramp up our capability. Tom, you want to add something?
Thomas Dooley

Yeah, the only thing I would say is that it's not possible to break out the incremental revenue associated with it because it's part of, as Philippe said, the overall relationship we have with those advertisers. Whenever a Vantage product is introduced, it does certainly introduce this part of an expanded economic relationship with the advertiser.
Philippe Dauman
And it's been very, very strict.
Thomas Dooley
And in high demand.
Brian Wieser
Great. Thank you very much.
Operator
We'll take our next question from Vasily Karasyov with CLSA.
Vasily Karasyov

Thank you very much. I think, Tom, you said that MTV and Comedy Central ratings need to improve for you to see advertising revenue growth. How much should they improve? Do you need them to grow year on year in 2017 to see ad revenue positive in the U.S. or just not be down 25%, 30%?
Thomas Dooley

Yeah, I think if they were down in the low teens, high single-digits, I think we'd be able to be in a positive position, given the growth that we have at the other network. So, we hope to be able to move into that type of situation, as Philippe indicated, as we move into 2017. The adjustment of our unit loads that we're putting in place this year will position us well to be able to do that, and we believe the programming that Comedy and MTV are putting on will position us to do that as we roll into next year.
Vasily Karasyov

Okay. And then one quick question. You mentioned that you see ad dollars coming from digital platforms back to pay TV. What kinds of digital are losing money? And what are your advertisers saying about the reason for that shift?
Thomas Dooley

Obviously, the Facebooks and the YouTubes of the world are doing very, very well in terms of growing dollars and that stays sound. It's the rest of the marketplace where there's been a lot of concern around fraudulent traffic delivery in the form of bot traffic. That has certainly fatigued advertisers' interest in those platforms. And money has come back in. And I believe that advertisers, as they look at the economic results of some of that digital advertising, have been less impressed and find television to be the platform it always has been, a very strong way to reach consumers.
Vasily Karasyov
All right. Thank you very much.
Operator
Our next comes from Ben Mogil with Stifel Nicolaus.
Benjamin Mogil

Hi. Good morning and thank you for taking my question. Wanted to talk a little bit about SVOD. So, when you look at the trends in SVOD, sort of parsing out domestic and international sort of separately, do you expect domestic to sort of be up or down for the year? And then when you look at international and some of the trends you're seeing, maybe talk a little bit about where you're seeing growth, either by geographies or by types of new services on the SVOD side that are coming in.

And when you look at some of the lessons that you sort of learned domestically about the impact on ratings, maybe talk a little bit about how, internationally, you're structuring things a little bit differently to reflect some of the things that you learned sort of in the domestic market. Thank you.
Philippe Dauman

So, as far as the domestic market, we have the three major distributors in Netflix, Amazon, and Hulu, and then we have some others emerging or in discussions, all of whom are looking for new compelling content as it is an increasingly competitive environment among them. So we continue to see that as a growing opportunity.

We are being selective in what programming we make available and what the windows are. And as I've talked about in prior earnings calls, we are differentiating among types of programming based on the performance that we see. And in many cases, we see a presence of our shows on SVOD, prior seasons, for example, as being an important marketing driver for a new season, a good vehicle for catch-up and other things of that nature.

In the international marketplace, clearly, it is a fast-growing opportunity. It is a significant opportunity in many countries where there's not a robust traditional delivery market. And importantly, we are seeing a lot of these SVOD services are local – not the ones that we talk about here in the U.S – there's a lot of local competition in the marketplace. The last time I looked at it, for example, in a country like China, there are seven major – and I'm sure several others beyond the seven majors that I was looking at – SVOD players that are local. But that's not just China, in many other places, you have local MVPDs that are setting up robust services. They watched what happened in the U.S., and so they got ahead of some of the U.S. players that have now expanded globally.

So in many countries, we're seeing the opportunity for us to be greater with local players than the U.S.-based services that are "exporting abroad." At the same time, we're doing a fair amount of business with the U.S.-based ones as they look for international growth. So overall, it's a good opportunity for us. And since you bring up international, the opportunity to distribute content on various mobile services, particularly in countries where there's not a real good established paid television infrastructure, is also a significant area of growth as we look in the future.
Benjamin Mogil
And in some of that selectivity around windowing of programming that you're doing domestically, are you employing a sort of similar tactic abroad?
Philippe Dauman

Well, every market is different. And in some markets, it's pretty close to [indiscernible] In a new developing market, it could be our primary form of distribution. So those markets obviously, we're happy to have our brands present in some way. That would be true at some markets in a place like Africa or certain countries in Southeast Asia, as one example. And China, of course, is a very difficult market for traditional non-Chinese players, so SVOD is, in China, a big primary opportunity for us to expose our brands and our shows for the day, hopefully, in the future where we will be able to have a greater presence in traditional forms of distribution.
Benjamin Mogil
That's great. Thank you very much for the color.
Philippe Dauman
Welcome.
Operator
We'll take our next question from Omar Sheikh with Credit Suisse.
Omar Sheikh

Morning, everyone. Just a couple of questions on Media Networks. First on affiliate revenues, could you give us the underlying domestic affiliate revenue growth in the quarter, excluding content licensing? I don't think you gave that in your prepared remarks. And could you perhaps remind us when we should expect the step down from AT&T to cycle out this year?

And secondly, on Media Networks expenses, you gave – I think, Tom, you gave guidance on programming costs growth for this year. I wonder if you could also give us guidance on total expense growth this year. And then longer term, Philippe, maybe if you could – now that you have some stability on domestic distribution, perhaps you could sort of update us on your thoughts on how you think about investing in the core network brands from next year and beyond. Thanks.
Philippe Dauman

Well, as far as I mentioned my remarks on the affiliate revenue, the adjustment for the AT&T direct renewal plays itself out through our fiscal year. That's why I referenced it being behind us as we head into 2017. And we don't break out specifically the categories with tighter revenue growth. And as Tom mentioned in his remark, there's a certain choppiness to the revenue recognition based on product availability in the SVOD space.

And before Tom responds to your questions as it relates to the expense items that you talked about, we always have – I just want to make an overall comment – as far as our programming expense and investment, we always have invested in programming and grown our investment in programming. It is the source of opportunity for us to monetize in different platforms around the world. And by the way, as our international business grows, they also are generating original programming, some of which is finding its way directly into the U.S. or formats. We have formats originating here or originating in our international networks. That will be a growing opportunity. And we are -- we have been shifting dollars from acquired programming to original programming, which will benefit us in all these new forms of distribution. Tom, you want to address the...
Thomas Dooley
Yeah. I'm going to invite Wade to address that, I think.
Wade Davis
Yeah, aggregate expense costs for the year should be in the mid-single-digits.
Omar Sheikh
Great. Thanks a lot.
Operator
We'll take our next question from [ph] Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Group.
Unidentified Analyst

Great. Thank you very much. First on measurement. I believe Viacom worked with comScore in the creation of their new cross-platform measurement service, but of course, you're also a customer of Nielsen. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the merit of each measurement service and how long you'll be customers of both.

My follow-up is on programming. With the rebuild at MTV and the new creation output at Comedy Central, as that is added to the schedule, is it possible that you might see less value in the prior programming that might cause some kind of write-down? Thanks.
Thomas Dooley

I'll take that measurement. We think Nielsen and comScore are both vital parts of the robust environment that's growing. In addition to other data suppliers that we append to the aggregate amount of information, we provide our advertisers with about the consumers that are consuming our programming that makes it more valuable to advertisers and helps them better refine the target audiences that they're trying to reach. Both services are doing very well, becoming very innovative and doing the best they can, given the samples they have to deal with. One is a very, very large sample. One is a sample of about 20,000 to 40,000 households. We think both have their attributes and we use them both to the fullest extent possible to provide our advertisers with the best possible information our audience delivers.
Philippe Dauman

As far as the programming, really, MTV we're adding programming. We have a lot of very successful shows on MTV, as I mentioned. We have a lot of the top shows in the 12 to 34 demographic. And whether it's the continued success of shows like Teen Mom or Shannara, which we have renewed, and Scream and so forth. But we're adding on a lot of programming, we're focusing on the M in MTV.

And Comedy Central also has a really strong line-up, and I mention a lot of the shows. And again, I think the imperative, as we go forward, is to add to the volume of compelling millennial-oriented original programming and events. I'll just mention the – going back to MTV – the great success of the reinvented MTV Movie Awards this year, where we improved overall viewership in what was a multicast show by over 50%. And I think it was a great representation of the brand done in a new way and you'll see a lot more of that as we go forward under new leadership.
James Bombassei
Operator, we have time for one more question.
Operator
Certainly. We'll take our final question from Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets.
Daniel Salmon

Hey, good morning, everyone. Philippe, as we've been discussing here this morning, Comcast has officially announced a deal to acquire DreamWorks for $41 a share. Just curious how you think that deal may or may not impact your discussions around the minority investment in Paramount.
Philippe Dauman

Well, I think it shows the value. Here you have DreamWorks Animation, a studio that puts out two movies a year. So I think if you take that and look at the incredible, rich history that resides in the Paramount library, which is huge in quantity and quality, you look at the number of franchises we have, you look at the 15 movies a year, major movies that we'll be putting out year after year, you look at the growing international potential. You look at the fact that we are in the animation business, as we have animated family-oriented titles going forward, or the franchises that we are growing out of Nickelodeon, such as Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and SpongeBob and others. So we have a very vital process.

Let me give you a few more details on the process. Obviously, we won't talk about specifics until we announce a result, but we have winnowed down from over 40 companies that expressed interest. We are in the final stages of winnowing that down to a handful of strong players. They will be receiving management presentations from this period until mid-May, after which we will get into detailed negotiation, discussion, diligence, all with a view to entering into an agreement, as I mentioned in my remarks, by the end of June.

There is strong interest from around the world and we think at this stage based on the conversations that I have had, that we will have a compelling result that will be both a strategic driver, reflect the significant value of Paramount, which, after all, is one of the greatest studios in Hollywood, with a 100-plus year history. So I think today's announcement is just a validation of the value of the highest form of content, which is motion picture content. And as I mentioned earlier, at Paramount, we have the great growth opportunity created by a new television production operation that in and of itself is a growth business for the future or Paramount.
James Bombassei
We want to thank everyone for joining us on our earnings call.
Operator
That does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
